text: <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a POZ / zinc-finger protein , is a sequence - specific transcriptional repressor .

Approximately 40 % of diffuse large cell lymphoma are associated with chromosomal translocations that deregulate the expression of the <extra_id_0> BCL6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene by juxtaposing heterologous promoters to the <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> coding domain .

text: The <extra_id_0> BCL6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene encodes a 95-kDa protein containing six C-terminal zinc-finger motifs and an N-terminal POZ domain , suggesting that it may function as a transcription factor .

By using a DNA sequence selected for its ability to bind recombinant <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in vitro , we show here that <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is present in DNA - binding complexes in nuclear extracts from various B-cell lines .

In transient transfectin experiments , <extra_id_0> BCL6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can repress transcription from promoters linked to its DNA target sequence and this activity is dependent upon specific DNA - binding and the presence of an intact N-terminal half of the protein .

We demonstrate that this part of the <extra_id_0> BCL6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> molecule contains an autonomous transrepressor domain and that two noncontiguous regions , including the POZ motif , mediate maximum transrepressive activity .

These results indicate that the <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein can function as a sequence - specific transcriptional repressor and have implications for the role of <extra_id_0> BCL6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in normal lymphoid development and lymphomagenesis .
